page.title: 04Long Barrow At Notgrove
page.content:
The Long Barrow of Notgrove, now grassed over, is a Neolithic Tomb of the Severn-Cotswold group and was used for collective burials about 2000BC. It has a central gallery with two pairs of side chambers built of large stones and a buried circular stone. Several human skeletons and Neolithic pottery excavated are now in Cheltenham Museum. The Monument is now in the care of the Ministry of Works. Admission is free to the site.
Analysis of charcoal found at this site revealed that Ash, Cherry, Elm and Hazel grew in this area 4000 years ago. The presence of the Hazel nuts gives rise to the name of the nearby village of Notgrove.
